taskDescription:
The height in feet, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi>h</mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">h</annotation></semantics></math>, of an object shot upwards into the air with initial velocity, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msub>
      <mi>v</mi>
      <mn>0</mn>
    </msub>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">{v_0}</annotation></semantics></math>, after <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi>t</mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">t</annotation></semantics></math> seconds is given by the formula <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi>h</mi>
  <mo>=</mo>
  <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
  <mn>16</mn>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mi>t</mi>
      <mn>2</mn>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
  <mo>+</mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msub>
      <mi>v</mi>
      <mn>0</mn>
    </msub>
  </mrow>
  <mi>t</mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">h = - 16{t^2} + {v_0}t</annotation></semantics></math>. A firework is shot upwards with initial velocity 130 feet per second. How many seconds will it take to reach a height of 260 feet? Round to the nearest tenth of a second.
